subject: Throttle 0 - 100 Too Fast
description_text:
Hi,

Early in the summer I ordered and received the Pro X Ultra pedals. After
initial set up hiccups, they have been great to use. This morning however I
noticed the throttle pedal was registering about 15% (with constant, small
fluctuations) of input. I've tried resolving it, but haven't succeeded,
hence my contacting you now.

First I checked the cables and noticed the clutch haptic  cable came close
to the connection point for the throttle pedal cable. I made sure to move
it further away, thinking it could be interference. Next I tried
recalibrating the pedals several times. I then tried the offset function
and followed the instructions (including disconnecting and reconnecting the
device when it was done). Next I tried recalibrating some more times, as
well as restarting my computer and the Simsonn software.

None of these attempts fixed the issues, though the issue did change a bit.
At first it was registering constant input at around the 15% mark. After
pressing the pedal, it went to 85% (roughly) without coming back down when
the pedal was released.

After doing calibration etc, the issue currently is that position seems to
be read accurately (the white bar moves smoothly with the pedal being
pressed), but the throttle input stays at 0% for maybe 40% of the travel,
then quickly jumps from registering input at 0% to input at 100% between
maybe 40% - 43% of the pedal travel, then stays at 100% for the rest of the
travel.

This is very different from before. I have always used to basic curve
setting (straight line), and would like to keep using it. With this new
behaviour though, that is unworkable and gives no control over the amount
of input registered. I checked the other curves to see if it might help,
but that is not the, they all have a very sudden jump from registering 0%
to suddenly registering 100% with barely a difference in pedal travel
distance between them. Screenshots below to hopefully illustrate more
clearly than I can put into words.

Could you please advise what I can try next to resolve this?

Best regards,

Dirk

conversations.body_text: Hi Dirk Deckers,    Please first check that the throttle pedal sensor/position is not physically damaged. Once confirmed, follow these steps:    Reconnect all three pedals to the control box.    Then reconnect the USB cable.    In the software, use the Offset function.    After completing this step successfully, the white signal bar of the pedal should return to 0%. Then perform a full pedal calibration again. Please test it and let us know if this resolves the issue.

Hi,

Thanks for the quick response. I've followed the steps and the problem has
not been resolved.

To confirm: checking that the pedal sensor/position is not physically
damaged means doing a visual inspection? I don't see any damage in any
case. Also, the pedals were working fine when I used them yesterday
evening, then weren't touched until I noticed the issue (based on the
throttle LED light cue) today.

Also, just making sure this part is clear: when the pedal is not pressed,
the bar next to 'Position' is fully grey. When I press the pedal gradually,
the white signal bar appears, consistent with the travel of the pedal. Then
close to halfway through the travel of the pedal, the previously grey bar
very quickly / sharply turns blue, in line with the percentage above the
bar shooting up to 100% very fast.

I'm not sure how the pedal is engineered, so I might be wrong about this,
but to me it looks like there are 2 sensors in play:
- a sensor keeping track of the distance of travel, which seems to be
working fine (visible through the white signal bar that appears /
disappears consistent with actual pedal travel)
- a (load cell) sensor keeping track of pressure applied, which seems to
now have very large dead zones both at the lower and upper end, where
before today it was more in line with the travel distance sensor

Br,

Dirk

On Sun, 21 Sept 2025 at 13:20, service@simsonn.com

Hi,

The issue is resolved. I'm not sure why it suddenly changed again and I'll
keep an eye on it for the future, but today I tried again with the above
steps and everything seems back to normal. It's a little worrisome that I
don't know why it changed suddenly, but if it stays like this, it's fine I
suppose.

Br,

Dirk

Hi Dirk Deckers,  The white progress bar corresponds to the pedal’s damping adjustment. If you have changed the pedal’s mechanical position, you can use the Offset function to reset the white bar to 0%, returning it to its initial position.
